references:
Results. We implement all methods with 404040 rounds444We observe very little gain after 404040 rounds: adding 606060 rounds only improves FedAvg (ConvNet) by 0.7%percent0.70.7\%., except for the one-round Ensemble. We assume that all clients are connected at every round. We set the local batch size as 404040.
Table 1 summarizes the results. FedBE outperforms the baselines by a notable margin. Compared to FedAvg, FedBE consistently leads to a 2∼9%similar-to2percent92\sim 9\% gain, which becomes larger as the network goes deeper. By comparing FedBE to FedBE (w/o SWA) and v-Distillation, we see the consistent improvement by SWA for distillation and Bayesian ensemble with sampled models. We note that, FedAvg outperforms 1-Ensemble and is on a par with v-Distillation555In contrast to Lin et al. (2020), we add weight decay to local client training, effectively improving FedAvg., justifying (a) the importance of multi-round training; (b) the challenge of ensemble distillation. Please see subsection C.2 for an insightful analysis.

We found that distillation with SGD is more sensitive to noisy labels and the number of epochs. For ResNet20 (Table 1), FedBE with FedAvg + C + S w/o SWA (i.e., using SGD) achieves 74.9%percent74.974.9\% with 20 epochs but 74.0%percent74.074.0\% with 40 epoch. In contrast, FedBE with SWA is much stable. As shown in Figure 11, the accuracy stays stable with more than 10 epochs being used, achieving 77.5%percent77.577.5\% with 20 epochs and 77.3%percent77.377.3\% with 40 epochs.

We follow the experimental setup in section 5 and further show the test accuracy of the compared methods at different communication rounds (in total 404040 rounds) in Figure 13. Specifically, we experiment with ResNet20 and ResNet32 for both the Step-non-i.i.d. and Dirichlet-non-i.i.d. settings on CIFAR-10 (the results at 404040 rounds are the same as those listed in Table 1). FedBE obtains the highest accuracy after roughly 10 rounds, and could gradually improve as more rounds are involved. Interestingly, v-Distillation, which performs ensemble directly over clients’ models without other sampled models, normally obtains the highest accuracy in the first 10 rounds, but is surpassed by FedBE after that. We hypothesize that in the first 10 rounds, as the clients models are still not well trained, the constructed distributions may not be stable. We also note that except 1-Ensemble, the other methods with ensemble mostly outperform FedAvg in the first 10 rounds, showing their robustness in aggregation.

references:
In terms of model aggregation.
Yurochkin et al. (2019) developed a Bayesian non-parametric approach to match clients’ weights before average, and FedMA (Wang et al., 2020) improved upon it by iterative layer-wise matching. One drawback of FedMA is its linear dependence of computation and communication on the network’s depth, not suitable for deeper models. Also, both methods are not yet applicable to networks with residual links and batch normalization (Ioffe & Szegedy, 2015). We improve aggregation via Bayesian ensemble and knowledge distillation, bypassing weight matching.
rather than relying on a single point estimate. While Equation 3 is intractable in general, we can approximate it by the Monte Carlo method, sampling M𝑀M models for model ensemble

where Ω=maxm⁡‖Ω(m)‖Ωsubscript𝑚normsuperscriptΩ𝑚\Omega=\max_{m}\|\Omega^{(m)}\|.
In federated learning, especially in the non-i.i.d. cases, ΩΩ\Omega can be quite large. Bayesian ensemble thus can have a notable difference (improvement) compared to FedAvg.

Results. We implement all methods with 404040 rounds444We observe very little gain after 404040 rounds: adding 606060 rounds only improves FedAvg (ConvNet) by 0.7%percent0.70.7\%., except for the one-round Ensemble. We assume that all clients are connected at every round. We set the local batch size as 404040.
Table 1 summarizes the results. FedBE outperforms the baselines by a notable margin. Compared to FedAvg, FedBE consistently leads to a 2∼9%similar-to2percent92\sim 9\% gain, which becomes larger as the network goes deeper. By comparing FedBE to FedBE (w/o SWA) and v-Distillation, we see the consistent improvement by SWA for distillation and Bayesian ensemble with sampled models. We note that, FedAvg outperforms 1-Ensemble and is on a par with v-Distillation555In contrast to Lin et al. (2020), we add weight decay to local client training, effectively improving FedAvg., justifying (a) the importance of multi-round training; (b) the challenge of ensemble distillation. Please see subsection C.2 for an insightful analysis.

We observed that applying weight decay in local client training improves all FL methods, but the suitable hyper-parameter can be different for different methods on different network architectures. Tuning it specifically for each method is thus essential for fair comparisons. We search the weight decay hyper-parameter for each network and each method in [1​e−3,1​e−4]1e31e4[1\mathrm{e}{-3},1\mathrm{e}{-4}] with a validation set.

For methods with distillation (FedBE and v-Distillation), We tune the epochs for v-Distillation from [1,5,10,20,30,40]1510203040[1,5,10,20,30,40] and find 202020 to be stable across different setups. We apply 202020 to FedBE as well.

We found that distillation with SGD is more sensitive to noisy labels and the number of epochs. For ResNet20 (Table 1), FedBE with FedAvg + C + S w/o SWA (i.e., using SGD) achieves 74.9%percent74.974.9\% with 20 epochs but 74.0%percent74.074.0\% with 40 epoch. In contrast, FedBE with SWA is much stable. As shown in Figure 11, the accuracy stays stable with more than 10 epochs being used, achieving 77.5%percent77.577.5\% with 20 epochs and 77.3%percent77.377.3\% with 40 epochs.

We follow the experimental setup in section 5 and further show the test accuracy of the compared methods at different communication rounds (in total 404040 rounds) in Figure 13. Specifically, we experiment with ResNet20 and ResNet32 for both the Step-non-i.i.d. and Dirichlet-non-i.i.d. settings on CIFAR-10 (the results at 404040 rounds are the same as those listed in Table 1). FedBE obtains the highest accuracy after roughly 10 rounds, and could gradually improve as more rounds are involved. Interestingly, v-Distillation, which performs ensemble directly over clients’ models without other sampled models, normally obtains the highest accuracy in the first 10 rounds, but is surpassed by FedBE after that. We hypothesize that in the first 10 rounds, as the clients models are still not well trained, the constructed distributions may not be stable. We also note that except 1-Ensemble, the other methods with ensemble mostly outperform FedAvg in the first 10 rounds, showing their robustness in aggregation.

of the main paper). Here we report results using a Dirichlet distribution for model sampling (cf.
in setting the parameter of a Dirichlet distribution. We see that the accuracy is not sensitive to the change of
with Dirichlet is slightly worse than
To further study the models sampled from the global model distribution constructed in

, we compare the prediction accuracy and confidences (the maximum values of the predicted probabilities) of clients’ models and sampled models. We show the histogram of correctly and incorrectly predicted test examples at different prediction confidences. As shown in

, we observe that clients’ models tend to be over-confident by assigning high confidences to wrong predictions. We hypothesize that it is because clients’ local training data are scarce and class-imbalanced. On the other hand, sampled models have much better alignment between confidences and accuracy (i.e., higher confidences, higher accuracy).

We experiment with Step-non-i.i.d. CIFAR-10 using ConvNet, and train the
epochs. We then compare (a) weight average to combine the models, (b) model ensemble, and (c) Bayesian model ensemble with

extra samples beyond weight average and individual clients. For (b) and (c), we further apply knowledge distillation using the unlabeled server data to summarize the ensemble predictions into a single global model using
. We note that, method (a) is equivalent to one-round
; method (b) without distillation is the same as 1-Ensemble; method (b) with
distillation is equivalent to one-round v-Distillation; method (c) with
shows the results with several interesting findings. First, without distillation, model ensemble clearly outperforms weight average and Bayesian model ensemble further adds a
. Second, summarizing model ensemble into one global model largely degrades the accuracy, showing the challenges of applying ensemble distillation in federated learning. The

accuracy by ensemble, although relatively higher than others, may still be far from perfect to be used as distillation targets.
Third, distillation with
for both model ensemble and Bayesian model ensemble, justifying our proposed usage of

. Fourth, with or without distillation, Bayesian model ensemble always outperforms model ensemble, with very little cost of estimating the global model distribution and performing sampling. Fifth, even with the degraded accuracy after distillation, model ensemble and Bayesian model ensemble, after distilled into a single model, still outperforms weight average notably. Finally, although in the one-round setting we hardly see the advantage of distilling the model ensemble into a single model, with multiple rounds of communication as in the main paper (cf.

), its advantage becomes much clear—it allows the next-round local training to start from a better initialization (in comparison to weight average) and eventually leads to much higher accuracy than 1-Ensemble.
